base_note.note_text:
PROCEDURE NOTE - INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY

DATE: 2025-01-19
PATIENT: Dorothy Williams
MRN: 1553685
DOB: 02/14/1940
AGE: 84 years old
SEX: Female

ATTENDING: Dr. Michael Santos, MD
LOCATION: Cardiac Pavilion, Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Recurrent bilateral pleural effusions
2. New York Heart Association Class IV heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (EF 15%)
3. Not candidate for mechanical circulatory support or transplant

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Left-sided tunneled indwelling pleural catheter (PleurX) placement

INDICATION: This 84-year-old female with end-stage heart failure has required hospitalization 6 times in the past 3 months for symptomatic bilateral pleural effusions despite maximum medical therapy. After multidisciplinary discussion including heart failure, palliative care, and IP, decision was made for left-sided IPC given larger effusion on left. Patient and family understand palliative intent.

ANESTHESIA: Local anesthesia only (2% lidocaine) - patient unable to tolerate any sedation given severity of cardiac dysfunction.

PROCEDURE:
Patient positioned semi-recumbent at 45 degrees (unable to lay flat due to orthopnea). Timeout completed. Ultrasound identified large left pleural effusion. Skin marked at 6th intercostal space, anterior axillary line.

Skin prepped with ChloraPrep. Local anesthesia infiltrated liberally along proposed tract. 3cm skin incision made. Tunneling device used to create 8cm subcutaneous tunnel anteriorly. PleurX 15.5Fr catheter threaded through tunnel.

Pleural space entered using Seldinger technique under ultrasound guidance. Catheter advanced without difficulty. Initial drainage of 800mL clear yellow fluid - drainage stopped per institutional protocol for heart failure patients (max 500-1000mL to avoid re-expansion issues and volume shifts).

Catheter secured with suture. Dry sterile dressing applied. Post-procedure portable CXR confirms good catheter position, no pneumothorax.

Fluid sent for: Cell count, chemistry, NT-proBNP

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None. Patient tolerated procedure well with no hemodynamic changes.

PLAN:
1. Overnight telemetry monitoring
2. Home health for IPC drainage teaching
3. Drainage frequency to be determined based on symptoms - anticipate every 2-3 days
4. Continue diuretics and guideline-directed medical therapy
5. Follow-up with heart failure team and IP clinic

Dr. Michael Santos, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent pleural effusions from end-stage heart failure

evidence.primary_indication: NYHA Class IV heart failure, EF 15%, recurrent bilateral effusions
evidence.anesthesia: Local anesthesia only - patient unable to tolerate sedation

clinical_context.primary_indication: Recurrent pleural effusions secondary to end-stage heart failure

code_rationales.32550: Insertion of tunneled indwelling pleural catheter (PleurX) for heart failure-related recurrent effusion. Palliative indication in end-stage HFrEF patient.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Appropriate code for IPC insertion. Heart failure is an accepted indication for tunneled catheter when medical therapy is maximized.

cpt_codes.description: Insertion of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff

variations.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE DOCUMENTATION
============================================================

PATIENT IDENTIFICATION AND DEMOGRAPHICS
----------------------------------------
Patient: As documented
Medical Record Number: 6788110
Date of Birth: 02/14/1938
Age at Procedure: 86 years
Procedure Date: N/A

CLINICAL INDICATION AND PREOPERATIVE ASSESSMENT
----------------------------------------
The patient presented with recurrent pleural effusions from end-stage heart failure. Following comprehensive multidisciplinary evaluation and informed consent discussion detailing procedural risks, benefits, and alternatives, the patient elected to proceed with the proposed intervention.

PROCEDURAL METHODOLOGY AND TECHNIQUE
----------------------------------------

Ipc:


INTRAPROCEDURAL FINDINGS
----------------------------------------
Detailed airway examination was performed with findings as documented in the procedural narrative.


POSTPROCEDURAL ASSESSMENT AND DISPOSITION
----------------------------------------
The procedure was completed without immediate complications. The patient demonstrated hemodynamic stability throughout and was transferred to the recovery area in satisfactory condition.

PROCEDURAL CODING DOCUMENTATION
----------------------------------------
Current Procedural Terminology Codes: 32550

This documentation has been prepared in accordance with institutional standards for procedural documentation and coding compliance.

PROCEDURE NOTE

Date: None
Patient: None
MRN: 9877472
Age/Sex: 80yo F

Attending Physician: [Attending]
Resident/Fellow: [Trainee, PGY-X]

INDICATION:
Recurrent pleural effusions from end-stage heart failure

CONSENT:
Informed consent obtained. Risks, benefits, and alternatives discussed.
Patient verbalized understanding and agreed to proceed.

TIMEOUT:
Performed. Correct patient, procedure, and site confirmed.

SEDATION:
Local only

PROCEDURE STEPS:
1. Patient positioned and monitored
2. Sedation administered per protocol
3. Topical anesthesia applied to airway
4. Ipc performed
5. Scope withdrawn
6. Patient recovered without complication

SPECIMENS:
As documented above

COMPLICATIONS:
None

EBL:
Minimal

DISPOSITION:
Inpatient admission

CPT CODES: 32550

ATTESTATION:
I was present for the entire procedure and agree with the above documentation.
[Attending Signature]

variations.note_text:
On None, None, a 83-year-old female (MRN 9199035), underwent bronchoscopic evaluation for Recurrent pleural effusions from end-stage heart failure. The patient received Local only and the procedure was performed in standard fashion. The procedure included ipc. 

On examination, the airways were systematically inspected. The procedure was completed without immediate complications. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Specimens obtained were sent for appropriate analysis and results will be reviewed at follow-up. The preliminary assessment is non-malignant. 

Procedural coding: 32550.
